LONDON, July 12.--The immigration of Jews into Palestine will be halted at the end of September and no new quota will be issued for the following six months because of the influx of illegal immigrants, Malcolm MacDonald, Colonial Secretary, announced today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12.--John J. Creeden, a member of the Philadelphia Police Bureau for twentynine years, who enhanced his reputation with the arrest of Al Capone on a gun-carrying charge in 1929, died in the Philadelphia General Hospital today after a year's illness. His age was 58 years.

ROME, July 12.--The names of the first Americans known to be involved in the expulsion of foreigners from Italian Tyrol were communicated to the United States Embassy here this morning, and Ambassador William Phillips promptly went to the Foreign Ministry to ask an explanation.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 12.-- Miss Rosalie Coe gave a luncheon followed by bridge today at The Appletrees.

The Manhattan realty deals reported yesterday reached into several sections of the borough. In many of the transactions investors figured as principals, and several buyers plan to rehabilitate their purchases in accordance with the provisions of the Multiple Dwelling Law.

WASHINGTON, July 12.--Three executive assistants to the President with "a passion for anonymity" and a reputation for getting things done were named by President Roosevelt today under the Reorganization Law, which authorized a salary of $10,000 a year for each of six helpers to the President. The three named by Mr. Roosevelt today were:

WASHINGTON, July 12.--The Senate confirmed Paul V. McNutt as Federal Security Administrator today after an airing in debate between Senators Bridges and Minton of the organization of the "Two Per Cent Club" of Indiana, under which State employes pay a levy on their salary into the Democratic party's war chest.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 12.-- Mrs. J.B. Balding of Women's National carded an 80 today to win the low-gross prize in a one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Huntington Country Club.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 12.-- "Cortez and Montezuma" will be filmed in Mexico in the Autumn by Miguel Torres, the producer announced today, as a result of negotiations with Mexican Federal officials. Both English and Spanish versions will be made, with the financing reportedly provided by the National Bank of Mexico.

HARLAN, Ky., July 12.--Guns of pickets and National Guardsmen killed a miner, seriously wounded a militia officer and felled four others today in the most serious of recent outbreaks of strife in the "Bloody Harlan" soft coal field. Two other miners were beaten.

The campaign to lower teachers' salaries in New York State as part of an economy drive is the first step in a "concerted attack on general wage standards throughout the nation," Dr. Bella V. Dodd, legislative representative of the New York State Federation of Teachers, warned 100 educators yesterday at a meeting at New York University's Washington Square center.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 12.-- Princeton University granted scholastic honors to 555 students, or 24 per cent of its undergraduate enrollment, for the 1938-39 academic year, it was announced today by Wilbur F. Kerr, university registrar.

Bliss Laughlin, Inc., the first steel company to issue a statement of earnings for the first half of this year, reported yesterday a net profit of $253,515 for the six months ended on June 30 after deductions for depreciation, Federal income taxes and other charges.

A new selling policy by which department stores, clubs and hotels must buy from wholesalers or, if direct from the company, buy at the wholesalers' set prices, was announced yesterday by National Distillers Products Corporation.
WASHINGTON, July 12.--A Senate investigation of "short selling" on the Chicago Board of Trade was proposed today by Senator Nye of North Dakota.

KANSAS CITY, July 12.--The National Federation of Business and Professional Women's Clubs went on record this afternoon against active support of the policy of reciprocal trade treaties with other nations.

A regional set-up to distribute style "propaganda" on boys' wear to the public was urged yesterday by Mrs. Mildred Wall, men's stylist of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., in an address at the convention of the Boys Apparel Buyers Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

ESSEX FELLS, N.J., July 12.-- Olin Cerrocki, long-hitting star of the Shore View public links in Brooklyn, shot a 71, one over par, to win a one-day tournament of the Metropolitan Golf Association today at the Essex Fells Country Club.

Some of the boys who work in the coca-cola booths near the Japanese Pavilion have been trying for weeks, now, to promote friendly relations with some of the Japanese girls, but nothing has come of it. One of them, however, got a bright idea the other day.
SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 12 (AP).-- Newspapers in Sofia hinted tonight that Germany had sponsored formation of a new Balkan bloc by Bulgaria and Yugoslavia.

Melio Bettina, world light heavyweight champion from Beacon, N.Y., will defend his crown against Billy Conn of Pittsburgh in a bout scheduled for fifteen rounds tonight at Madison Square Garden.

Lewisohn Stadium was the scene of a double debut last night, as Frieder Weissmann, German conductor, introduced himself to New Yorkers in a program that brought the first local performance of Benjamin Britten's Variations for String Orchestra on a Theme by Bridge. The evening also offered the Brahms "Tragic" overture and the Tchaikovsky Fifth symphony.

BOSTON, July 12 (AP).--A band of National League ancients removed some of the sting of their circuit's latest All-Star setback today by giving thirty former American League greats an 8-4 lacing in the Old Timers' game at Fenway Park.

The first break in the resistance of the World's Fair Corporation to public demands that it reduce its admission price from 75 to 50 cents to let more persons attend and thus raise the attendance figures, which have lagged far behind official advance estimates, came yesterday.

PARIS, July 12.--The commemoration of the 150th anniversary of the outbreak of the French Revolution and the capture of the Bastille by a Paris mob got under way today with the hoisting outside of the Hotel de Ville, in the presence of President Albert Lebrun and members of the government, of the largest tricolor flag ever made.

VENTNOR CITY, N.J., July 12. --Six adjourned games were decided in the Ventnor City Chess Club's invitation tournament on the Municipal Pier today. Only one match from the sixth round was held over.

WASHINGTON, July 12.--An aircraft engine of "completely new design," combining large horsepower with small size, has completed a 150-hour test at the laboratories of the Army Air Corps at Wright Field, Dayton.

LONDON, July 12.--Brig. Gen. Charles Granville Bruce, leader of Mount Everest expeditions in 1922 and 1924, died today at the age of 73. As a climber and explorer, he had unrivaled knowledge of the Himalayas, under whose shadow he had spent practically the whole of his military career with Indian mountain troops.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 12. --An appeal to the State Mediation Board to end the conflict between Locals 60 and 147 of the International Hod Carriers, A.F. of L., was announced here today.

WASHINGTON, July 12.--President Roosevelt today retained the key to plans for adjournment of Congress as leaders groped about for strategy by which they might push forward the Neutrality Bill and the lending program, action on both of which he has demanded before the session ends.
A new apartment house project was announced yesterday in connection with the assembling of a plot on Washington Heights by a builder.
Modernization of old brownstone houses in the Carl Schurz Park neighborhood on the upper East Side of Manhattan is proceeding apace.
WASHINGTON, July 12.--President Roosevelt and many other Federal dignitaries attended the opening tonight of the National Symphony Orchestra's third Summer season of "Sunset Symphonies."

The Brazilian military mission to the United States, headed by Major Gen. Pedro Aurelio de Goes Monteiro, Chief of Staff of the Army of Brazil, spent twelve hours yesterday at the World's Fair, where several special events were presented in its honor.

NANTUCKET, Mass., July 12.--A ten-knot westerly gave the Eastern Yacht Club fleet a speedy slide down Nantucket Sound today in the third run of the sixty-seventh annual cruise.

The Associated Gas and Electric Company announced yesterday that Francis P. Cummings had resigned as a member of the board of directors and as consulting vice president. Mr. Cummings, it was said, had been seriously ill for several months. His successor has not been chosen.

Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., and F.S. Moseley Co. have won the award of $200,000 of school bonds of Indianapolis, Ind., on their bid of 100,949 for 2 s. The bonds, dated July 17, are to mature on April 1, 1941 to 1960.

World stocks of refined copper on June 30 were 513,670 tons, compared with 520,898 on May 31, a decline of 7,228, according to the Copper Institute. Blister stocks decreased 11,402 tons, making the net decline 18,630 tons.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 12.--Two transatlantic clipper ships, one bound east, the other west, were flying tonight between the United States and Europe. Aboard the eastbound Dixie Clipper were the oldest and youngest persons ever to fly over the Atlantic Ocean.

The current nation-wide furor created by the price claims made in passenger-car tire advertising in recent weeks provides concrete evidence that it is no longer possible to get away with extravagant or misleading copy, advertising executives pointed out yesterday.

THERE has been due warning from the Boxing Commission that Jimmy Grippo, mana ger of Melio Bettina, will not be allowed to make any hypnotic passes at Billy Conn of Pittsburgh in Madison Square Garden this evening. But how can they prevent it?

LONDON, July 12.--Judged by ordinary Fascist standards, so people in London think, the transfer of Count Dino Grandi from the Italian Embassy in London to a post in the Cabinet at Rome is a sign of his returning favor.

Buyer activity continued brisk in most of the wholesale markets here yesterday. While inspection of dress and coat lines reached a high point, it was noted that activity in accessory lines was also beginning earlier than usual.

A proclamation issued yesterday by the Graphic Arts Forum, 120 West Forty-fifth Street, calls upon "all artists and editors, designers and printers, typographers and advertising men, production and manufacturing men to boycott all printing and art materials that are manufactured in Nazi Germany."

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, July 12.--Count Galeazzo Ciano, the Italian Foreign Minister, with his suite flew across Northern Spain this morning from Barcelona to Vitoria and then proceeded by automobile to the palatial private residence put at their disposal for the next three days in Zarauz, a picturesque Basque coast resort several miles west of here.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 12.-- Drastic changes in the Constitution never come unless demanded by a majority of the people, Senator James F. Byrnes of South Carolina, one of President Roosevelt's legislative leaders, asserted tonight in addressing the American Bar Association.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 12.-- Arriving here late last night after a tiring automobile trip from Louisville, Frank Parker of Pasadena, Calif., began his defense of the Clifford Hemphill Challenge Trophy today in the Spring Lake invitation tennis tournament at the Bathing and Tennis Club.

The estate of the late Nicholas Goelz at 652 Bergenline Avenue, from Thirty-third to Thirty-fourth Street, Union City, N.J., has been sold to the 652 Bergenline Corporation, headed by New York investment interests.
WASHINGTON, July 12.--The voters of the United States, who Paul V. McNutt hopes will elect him President next year, are about to behold a very interesting and determined politician in action.

WASHINGTON, July 12.--The first breach in the Administration program for old-age assistance based on equal contributions by the Federal and State Governments was effected in the Senate today by a coalition of Southern members and New Deal followers on both sides of the chamber.

Dwight L. Hoppingarner, executive head of the American Construction Council, suggested yesterday that difficulties over the payment of union wages on WPA projects could be overcome if Congress made provision for a continuance of the heavy engineering and other public building programs under private contract.

BISLEY CAMP, England, July 12 (Canadian Press).--Twelve out of sixteen Canadian military marksmen today qualified for the second stage of the classic King's Prize, the premier event of the imperial meeting of the National Rifle Association.

There is no happier community at the World's Fair than the tiny troupers of the microvivarium in the Westinghouse Building, but for the first three weeks of the big show they were as glum as professional mourners.

Another steamship company will join the group of transportation organizations which has grown up in the various buildings of Rockefeller Center when the NorwegianAmerica Line takes possession, in September, of space just leased in the Palazzo d'Italia.

The retirements of Hale Holden, chairman, and three other New York directors of the Southern Pacific Company and other changes which will shift its management to San Francisco were announced yesterday. They have been replaced by Pacific Coast men.

DANZIG, July 13 (AP).--Telephoned reports from Berchtesgaden, Germany, tonight stated that Chancellor Adolf Hitler conferred for two hours during the day with Albert Foerster, Nazi leader of Danzig. The report said Herr Foerster expressed the hope "to see the Fuehrer in Danzig soon."

BOSTON, July 13 (AP).--Mrs. Emil Denemark's Upstream came from far off the early pace today to score a two-and-a-half-length victory in the $1,200 allowance mile-and-a-sixteenth feature at Suffolk Downs.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP).-- Paul V. McNutt moved into the Roosevelt Administration's high circles today, taking office as the first Federal Security Administrator.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 13.-- An appellate court ruling on whether the Court of Common Pleas or the Juvenile Court in Bergen County has jurisdiction over two 15-year-old boys accused of assault with intent to kill was in prospect today as the result of a dispute between two judges.

The excess reserves of member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased sharply in the week ended on Wednesday, chiefly as the result of the return flow of currency after the July 4 holiday expansion and the heavy Treasury payments in the week.
MONTREAL, July 13 (AP).--The Montreal Royals, bidding for higher levels in the International baseball standings, handed Newark a 3-2 defeat tonight.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 13.-- Several luncheons were given today at the Southampton Beach Club. Mrs. Robert G. Johnson gave one there for Mrs. Edward A. Strong, who is visiting Mrs. R. Swift Maguire at the Playhouse.

WASHINGTON, July 13.--New York is one of "eight or ten" cities in which the Department of Justice is preparing for grand jury investigations into trade restraints in the building construction industry, Attorney General Murphy said at his press conference today.
LENOX, Mass., July 13.--With six Berkshire garden clubs cooperating, the Lenox Horticultural Society opened its forty-fourth annual two-day flower show today at the Lenox Town Hall.

OLD ORCHARD BEACH, Me., July 13 (AP).--Future book supporters of Peter Astra in the 1939 Hambletonian received added assurance of their favorite's chances today when the sleek bay son of Peter Volo--Astra captured the national stake for 3-year-old trotting Hambletonian eligibles in straight heats.

Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, pioneer in the feminist movement, yesterday charged women with responsibility for continuation of war. She made her declarations in two speeches at the World's Fair in observance of Pan-Hellenic Day under the auspices of the Fraternity Women's Committee for the World's Fair.
PORTSMOUTH, N.H., July 13.-- The bow of the wrecked submarine Squalus shot almost vertically out of the water late today in the midst of salvage operations.
WASHINGTON, July 13.--Next in the Administration's fight to revise the Neutrality Act is likely to be a gesture to keep its own record clear rather than to force Congressional action.

TORONTO, July 13 (AP).--Toronto made it four straight tonight as the Leafs defeated Jersey City, 8--3, and toppled the Little Giants from the International Baseball League leadership, below Rochester.

Mayor La Guardia has notified bus companies operating in New York that he is working with other municipal officials on a plan for rerouting many buses and for "redistribution of terminal facilities" probably with a view to creating a new union bus terminal or group of central terminals, it was learned yesterday.

American Woolen Company yesterday announced prices on Summer suiting fabrics for 1940 which showed advances of 12 cents a yard over last year for tropical worsteds and from 12 to 17 cents a yard for gabardines.

General Rafael Leonidas Trujillo y Molina, former president of the Dominican Republic, visited the World's Fair yesterday for a luncheon as the guest of Mr. and Mrs. Grover A. Whalen at Perylon Hall and an inspection afterward of the Dominican Republic's exhibit.

WASHINGTON, July 13.--President Roosevelt told the Senate today that he could not accede to its request to return the notice of confirmation of Elmer D. Davies to be district judge for the Middle District of Tennessee.

After having been carried on for more than six months, hearings on various plans of reorganization for the bonds of the Ritz Tower Hotel at Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street are nearing an end and it appears likely that early action will be forthcoming to give this property a new start.

Three recently remodeled flats in scattered sections of Manhattan changed hands in one deal reported yesterday and several other tenement properties were taken by new owners who plan to rehabilitate and alter their purchases.
TOKYO, July 13.--The Japanese Cabinet today approved the government's propasals for the conference with Britain's representatives and these were subsequently submitted to the Emperor.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 13.-- Leading all the way, the Foxhunters and Los Rancheros bagged their third straight victories today to continue as the Meadow and Brook League pace-setters in the Hempstead Cups tourney for twelvegoal polo teams.

WASHINGTON, July 13.--The omnibus bill revising the Social Security Act was adopted by the Senate late today by a vote of 56 to 8, but it was amended to compel every State to pay from its own funds $10 to each recipient of oldage assistance in order to qualify for Federal aid.

CHICAGO, July 13.--Colonel F.C. Harrington, WPA Commissioner, stood firmly today behind the new Federal Relief Law in the face of strikes by WPA workers, put by the WPA at 92,770 as of Wednesday, and clamor from labor unions for revision of the law.

An investing client of King King, Inc., brokers, has purchased from the Three Star Building Corporation the six-story apartment house on the northwest corner of Eighty-third Street and Thirty-fifth Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens.

KANSAS CITY, July 13.--Delegates to the biennial convention of the National Federation of Business and Professional Women nominated a double slate of officers today, with Mrs. Rosa E. Cunningham of Des Moines, and Dr. Minnie L. Maffett of Dallas, as opponents for the presidency. The election will take place tomorrow.

CHICAGO, July 13.--Minor price changes, many of them reductions, the more lavish use of color, and a revolutionary style of make-up featured the Fall and Winter catalogue of Montgomery Ward Co., sent out to mail order customers today.

Sidney Howard, interviewed in a taxicab as it glided across town, revealed that he had finished the first act of his dramatization of Carl Van Doren's Pulitzer Prize-winning biography "Benjamin Franklin," which is due in the Fall.
WASHINGTON, July 13.--Attorney General Murphy joined the "Roosevelt for Third Term" movement among Cabinet members today.

A denial of all charges preferred against the American Federation of Actors, headed by Sophie Tucker, was made yesterday in a statement by Ralph Whitehead, the union's executive secretary, and Abraham J. Halprin, attorney.

The great collection of Italian paintings and sculpture given by Samuel H. Kress to the National Gallery of Art in Washington, D.C., comprises about 60 per cent of his entire collection, it was learned here yesterday.

ROME, July 13.--The Italian Government has protested to the French Government against the cession of the Hatay Republic to Turkey, it was announced today. As a member of the San Remo conference of 1920 that granted the Syrian mandate to France, Italy now makes the "fullest reservations" against the transfer.

Information contained in confidential reports of physicians to the Health Department giving the causes of deaths will be made available to the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, it was revealed yesterday, under a stipulation that the knowledge will be used for statistical purposes only and in no case in the settlement of an insurance claim.

Mrs. Flora Scholle Ehrmann, music patron and philanthropist and the widow of Ernest Ehrmann, banker and real estate man, died yesterday in her home, 16 East Forty-ninth Street, in which she had resided for seventy-two years. Mrs. Ehrmann, who had long been ill, was 79 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 (AP)-- Dr. Edmund Heller, naturalist and director of the Fleishhacker Zoo here since 1935, died last night of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

TRENTON, July 19.--The drafting of a bill to regulate horse racing with pari-mutuel betting in New Jersey was completed here today by an all-Republican committee of ten legislators. It will be submitted to the Attorney General's Department for an opinion as to its legality and then copies will be sent to each member of the Senate and Assembly for study.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 19. --The Maidstone Club tonight opened its series of weekly buffet dinners followed by backgammon and other games. After this week these events will take place on Thursdays.

Selection of a blue-ribbon jury and two alternate jurors, all men, was completed yesterday in the Brooklyn Supreme Court for the trial of Alexander R. Baldwin, staff assistant to District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan of Brooklyn, on charges of accepting an $800 bribe...

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 19.-- The close call of Jack Crawford of the Australian Davis Cup team in a beautifully played match with John Doeg of Rumson, N.J., and the defeat of David Freeman, national junior champion from Pasadena...

KANSAS CITY, July 19.--Larry MacPhail, red-headed president of the Dodgers, believes Manager Bill Terry of the Giants should be fined $5,000 "for making a farce out of baseball by the way they're torturing umpires" and told him so today over the telephone.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 19.-- Many members of the Summer colony of this resort and neighboring communities attended the opening of the annual flower show of the Mount Desert Garden Club at the Building of Arts today. The choicest flowers of many of the estates of Mount Desert Island were on display.

Efrem Zimbalist will be violin soloist in an all-Sibelius program to be given at the Lewisohn Stadium tonight by the Philharmonic-Symphony under the direction of Alexander Smallens. The program consists of "Finlandia," Romance in C...
Tenement houses in scattered sections of Manhattan passed to new control in deals reported yesterday.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 19 (AP).-- Intense diplomatic activity by the leaders of Bulgaria's foreign policy indicated tonight the importance they attach to the present London visit of Prince Paul, Regent of Yugoslavia.

A jurisdictional conflict between the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, now outside both the A.F. of L. and C.I.O., and the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, C.I.O. affiliate, reached an active stage yesterday when the garment workers' cloak joint board...

Congressional investigators, seeking a link between the Communist party and unrest on WPA projects, directed WPA officials in this city yesterday to supply them with a full list of participants in stoppage demonstrations called by the Workers Alliance and the WPA Teachers Union, Local 453, an affiliate of the American Federation of Labor.

Samuel Reshevsky, United States champion; Reuben Fine, Israel A. Horowitz, Albert S. Pinkus and Anthony E. Santasiere were leading in their several sections after the third and fourth rounds of the annual championship preliminaries of the American Chess Federation at the Hotel George Washington yesterday.

LONDON, July 19.--The fate of President Roosevelt's neutrality proposals had a depressing effect upon London today, especially as the news from Washington coincided with an ugly deadlock in the AngloPolish loan negotiations and with continued failure to make headway in the three-power negotiations in Moscow.

HOLLYWOOD, July 19.--"Saturday's Children," Maxwell Anderson's play of a decade ago, which reached the screen in 1929 as a part talking picture, will be re-made by Warners, the studio disclosed today.

The foreign exchange market turned easier here yesterday, re flecting the better demand abroad for the dollar before the local market opened. The rates continued easier through to closing. The undertone of the market was steady and the volume of business done was comparatively small.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--The ninety-first anniversary of the first Women's Rights Convention, which was held at Seneca Falls, N.Y., was celebrated tonight by the National Woman's Party in the gardens of Alva E. Belmont House on...

The downward plunge of Colonel Bill Terry's shell-shocked and bedridden Giants went on yesterday at the Polo Grounds without interruption and with scarcely a deviation in what seems to have become a set program.

The Coast Guard inquiry into the crash of the seaplane V-164, in which three lives were lost, turned yesterday to the broad question of whether flights to sea to bring in sick persons were not more hazardous than valuable.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 19. --Mrs. Hudson Budd gave a dinner and bridge tonight at Pine Tree Cottage for Mrs. Gray Dunnington of Montebello, Orange, Va., who has joined her and Mr. Budd for a visit.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 19.-- Charles F. Gladfelter, former business executive in the Hearst newspaper organization, died of a heart attack today in his home here. He had been in poor health three years.

PARIS, July 19.--Those responsible for the direction of French diplomatic policy admit that the adjournment until the next session of Congress of the discussion and possible amendment of the United States Neutrality Act constitutes a setback the consequences of which cannot as yet be estimated.

So much attention has been paid to the slum-clearance and lowincome housing provisions of the State's new public-housing statute that other features of the law designed to encourage the construction of apartments for persons of higher income have been overlooked in many quarters.

The Palace Theatre, long a landmark in Times Square, will receive a new streamlined front, it was announced yesterday by RKO Theatres. The alterations, including lobby decorations and a new marquee, will begin Monday night...

MILLINOCKET, Me., July 19.--A bloodhound today followed the trail of Donn Fendler Jr., 12, of Rye, N.Y., to the brink of Saddle Slide, a 400-foot precipice high above Mount Katahdin's timber line. When the hound stopped at the edge of the rocky slide, a posse of 106 men camped there for the night.

With the blessings of a priest and a "pep talk" by Police Commissioner Valentine, the force of the Eighth Precinct moved back yesterday into the Mercer Street station, one of the oldest in the city. Its old tenement house aspect wiped away by a $190,386 renovation, the station took its place among the city's modernized public buildings.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--An assertion that protracted delays by the National Labor Relations Board in making decisions were robbing the Wagner act of its effectiveness was made today by John Green, president of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, a C.I.O. affiliate in testifying before the House Labor Committee.

A feminine legion capable through sheer force of numbers of presenting through its membership an international pageant scaled to the proportions of the World's Fair took over the Court of Peace yesterday for that purpose. The spectacle involved a vividly costumed cast of 10,000 members of the Woman's Benefit Association, which is in convention at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

MOSCOW, July 19.--The Soviet Baltic Fleet, which recently returned to its base at Kronstadt after elaborate Spring manoeuvres has put to sea again on new exercises, it was announced officially tonight.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 19.--Mr. and Mrs. C. Ledyard Blair entertained with a large dinner at Honeysuckle Lodge tonight. Mrs. Hamilton McK. Twombly had luncheon guests at Vinland.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--The Iowa Public Service Company of Sioux City filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement giving details of a refunding operation involving issuance of $14,250,000 of 3 per cent first mortgage bonds due on Aug. 1, 1969.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 19. --Members of the Campfire Club of America responsible for the shooting of stray dogs on the club property at Briarcliff Manor and then hiding the carcasses are lacking in "common decency and sportsmanship," a Westchester County grand jury said today in a presentment handed up to County Judge Frank H. Coyne.

LIMA, Peru, July 19 (AP).--The Peruvian Foreign Office asserted today that two Peruvian Civil Guardsmen were killed yesterday when Ecuadorean troops made "a surprise attack" on the disputed frontier between the two nations.

A banking group headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. won yesterday $3,950,000 of various bonds issues of Boston, on a bid of 100.19 for $3,450,000, maturing on Aug. 1, 1940 to 1949, as 2s, and $500,000, due on Aug. 1, 1940 to 1959, as 1 s, or at a net interest to the city of 1.915523 per cent. The bonds were reoffered...

HONOLULU, July 19 (AP).--Victory in the 2,085-mile San Francisco-to-Hawaii yacht race, it appeared today, rested between the fifty-five-foot New York cutter Blitzen, already checked in, and the tiny thirty-six-foot Magic Carpet, reported sighted eighty-five miles from its destination at 11 A.M. (5:30 P.M., Eastern Daylight Saving Time).

O. HENRY has been dead for nearly thirty years. Thirty-five years ago he was living in New York, writing stories of the kind that had already made him famous. Forty years ago he was a convict in the Federal ward of the Ohio State Penitentiary, to which he had been sentenced on charges of embezzlement. Forty-five years ago he was in Austin, Texas, working for the First National Bank.

OCEAN CITY, Md., July 19.-- Somewhere along the road between New York and this small fishing port will be found a first-class jinx, for when we put out yesterday morning it took only an hour to realize our luck had changed for the better. When we put into port at night we had no marlin aboard, but we had sighted several and had raised one behind the bait.

LANSING, Mich, July 19 (AP).-- Governor Luren D. Dickinson sought tonight to soften the rebuke made in statements last week about the peril to young girls involved in social events such as he saw in connection with the conference of Governors held in Albany and New York City.
Elaine Barrie Barrymore, the estranged wife of John Barrymore, yesterday received an award of $4,062.50 in salary due from the producers of "My Dear Children " the play in which she appeared with...

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP).-- David Lilienthal, director of the Tennessee Valley Authority, envisioned for President Roosevelt today a bright future for the Tennessee Valley Authority, predicting it would be "making money" soon and estimating that its eventual revenues would be $25,000,000 annually.
Clarence S. Rose gave a dinner last night for his son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Duke of Jacksonville, Fla., in the Rainbow Room of Rockefeller Center.

TOKYO, Thursday, July 20.--The Anglo-Japanese conversations were resumed yesterday by Hachiro Arita, Japanese Foreign Minister, and Sir Robert Leslie Craigie, British Ambassador. The talks lasted all day and were adjourned last evening till tomorrow.

Jerome N. Frank, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and three member, of the New York Stock Exchange's new four-man public examining board were luncheon guests yesterday of Edward E. Bartlett Jr., chairman, and William McC. Martin Jr., presi-...

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., July 19.--Whereas yesterday indications pointed to a celebration party at Inwood tomorrow night after Tony Longo's stupendous 66 on the Wheatley Hills course in the opening round of the Long Island open golf championship, invitation were recalled and held in abeyance following red-headed Al Brosch's performance today.

City agencies moved yesterday to whip the plans for the BatteryBrooklyn vehicular tunnel into shape for submission for Federal financing as soon as the Administration's $2,660,000,000 lending program for self-liquidating projects becomes effective.

Ronald Nash, for months one of the country's leading young riders, lost his "bug," otherwise his apprentice allowance, at Empire City yesterday, but he celebrated his last day as an apprentice by scoring a triple. Giving a fine display of riding form, he won with True Call in the fourth race, Throttle Wide in the following event and Cristalina in the last.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--Domestic politics atop a stubborn stratum of isolationism in the Senate has prevented the President and Secretary Hull from making the contribution to enforced peace which they believe was implicit in their proposed revisions of the socalled Neutrality Law.
BERLIN, July 19.--Statistically German foreign trade returns for June, inclusive of Austria and Memelland but not the Protectorate, make an exceedingly favorable showing in both imports and exports.

LONDON, July 19.--The British Air Force today followed up its successful flight over France last week by sending another hundred-odd bombers on the same mission. This time some of the planes went as far as Marseille and covered about 1,400 miles before returning to their bases in the Midlands.
A large leasing transaction which doubles the space occupied by the lessee in the Garment Center was reported yesterday.
A supper dance was given last night at the Fairway Yacht Club, East Fifty-second Street and the East River, to aid the Bide-A-Wee Home Association, Inc., which for...

ROME, July 18.--Pope Pius XII, will plan and work over his first encyclical during his seclusion at Castel Gandolfo, it is learned. The first messages of the Popes are generally considered their most important because they usually embody the ideas and policies that set the tone of a reign.

A process by which discharge printing may be used on acetate rayon fabrics has been developed by Celanese Corporation of America. The development will make available to Celanese a considerable market, especially in street-wear ...

The committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange authorized yesterday the listing upon official notice of issuance of 70,000 additional no-par value common shares of Thompson Products, Inc., bringing to 398,572 the number of shares authorized to be listed on the Exchange.

JONES BEACH, L.I., July 19.-- Former Governor Alfred E. Smith, speaking here today at the tenth birthday party of the Jones Beach State Park, said the park did not show its age because it was well treated. In fact, he added, it was better than when it was dedicated.

BRATISLAVA, Slovakia, July 19. --Reports issued by the official press bureau, which should therefore be accepted with caution, indicate that the Ruthenians' resistance to Hungarian rule is increasing.

Earl Bartlett, a 16-year-old New Orleans schoolboy who says he will not allow tennis to interfere with his plans to become a physician, scored a surprising victory over Sidney B. Wood Jr., top-seeded player, in the Eastern clay court singles championship yesterday at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club.

CHICAGO, July 19.--Corn futures tumbled 1 1/8 to 1 cents a bushel today to the lowest level in more than five years as prospects of a huge new corn crop to augment a high record carryover caused buyers to stay out of the market.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., July 19.-- Detective Francis B. McGee of Ocean County, retired New York police detective sergeant, died yesterday at the Paul Kimball Hosiptal here after an emergency appendectomy. He was 67 years old and lived here.

CHICAGO, July 19.--Although showing a seasonal decline of 13 per cent from May, sales of reporting retail furniture Stores in June ran 11 per cent ahead of last year, the National Retail Furniture Association announced today. The increase of 11 per cent from June

Formal suit challenging the right of the Department of Sanitation employes to occupy their new palatial Summer vacation home, Sanity Hill, in alleged violation of zoning regulations of the town of Huntington, L.I., was begun yesterday by the town board.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--A net operating postal surplus of $10,000,000 for the fiscal year ended June 30, and revenues totaling $745,093,350, the highest for any year in the history of the service, were reported today by Postmaster General Farley.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--The Press Company, Inc., of Albany, and the Gannett Company, Inc., of Rochester, were ordered by the National Labor Relations Board today to stop "discouraging" membership in the Tri-City Newspaper Guild of Albany, Troy and Schenectady, or in any other labor organization.

Initial purchases of apparel for Fall, totaling from $4,000,000 to $4,500,000, representing a new record for the company, are being made by the thirty-five buyers of Coldblatt Brothers, Inc., Chicago, in the markets here, it was stated...

LONDON, July 19.--President Roosevelt today invited Earl Winterton, chairman of the Inter-Governmental Committee on Refugees; Sir Herbert Emerson, director, and the five vice chairmen to confer with him in Washington early in September on means of speeding up permanent settlement of the victims of Nazi "racial" and political persecution.

PARIS, July 19.--A star so heavy that a mere cubic inch of its matter weighs nearly 9,000 tons was described to the Singer-Polignac Congress of Astrophysics here this morning by Dr. G.P. Kuiper of Yerkes and McDonald Observatories.

ROME, July 19.--The story that a trade agreement had been reached with Germany to give her a "free zone" in the port of Trieste similar to that formerly enjoyed by Austria was met with denials or professions of ignorance here today.

HANOVER, N.H., July 19.--Dr. Paul Cornell, president of the Romford School at Washington, Conn., predicted here today that because propaganda could accomplish nothing great or basic, the New Deal would surely founder on "that granite rock of economic fact--12,000,000 unemployed."

DANZIG, July 19.--Twenty former members of Marxist organizations have been arrested here in the last few days and are facing trial on charges of high treason, it was announced today. A sensational story is told in this connection of plans to destroy the Danzig gas works and carry out other acts of sabotage.

CHICAGO, July 19.--Excellent pitching by Jack Knott and Johnny Rigney, backed by a batting attack that produced twenty-four hits, gave the White Sox a sweep of their double-header today with the Red Sox, 4 to 1 and 8 to 0. The secondplace Boston club thus dropped to nine games behind the Yankees.

The 300 smartly uniformed young men who comprised the information cadets corps at the World's Fair, which was dissolved yesterday, were carefully selected from among 5,000 applicants for the jobs and since the opening of the Fair they had established a reputation for politeness and ingenuity in the face of the most absurd questions.

Farmers in and near the metropolitan area are faced for the second time within two months with the loss of millions of dollars in crops and dairy products as the result of what the Weather Bureau described last night as the worst July drought in local records.

The three store and apartment buildings, each on a plot 20 by 100 feet, at 286, 288 and 296 Legion Street, Brooklyn, have been sold by the Kings County Savings Bank to an investing client of Hyman M. Resnick, attorney. Taylor and Roberts were the attorneys for the seller.

HAVANA, July 19.--President Federico Laredo Bru today signed a decree to protect foreign concerns exporting to Cuba and banking institutions here on exchange operations abroad in view of the discount at which the Cuban peso is quoted.
SALUDA, N.C., July 19 (AP).-- Captain James Dinkins, retired New Orleans banker, died today in the Summer home here of his daughter, Mrs. C.G. Robinson. He was 94 years old.

Umpire trouble (What, again!) threatened for a time to bring out the reserves at Ebbets Field last night, where a crowd of 27,665 saw the Dodgers drop a ten-inning 4-2 thriller to the pace-setting Reds.

LOS ANGELES, July 19.--Miss Marjorie Dulin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Shelton Dulin, was married at the family home here yesterday afternoon to Benjamin Singleton Lackland of New York, son of Mrs. C.E. Lackland of Richmond, Va., and the late Mr. Lackland.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 20.--While Aaron Sapiro, attorney of Los Angeles, continued his testimony today in the Harry Bridges deportation hearing, Dean James M. Landis of Harvard Law School, special examiner, sought to narrow the testimony to matters relevant to the issue of deportation.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 20.-- Summoning his last bit of rapidly fading energy, Jack Crawford of the Australian Davis Cup team barely averted the loss of the fourth set by the margin of a point to eke out victory over Gardnar Mulloy of Coral Gables, Fla., today in the Longwood Bowl invitation...

TANNENBERG, Germany, July 20.--Col. Gen. Walther yon Brauchitsch, Commander-in-Chief of the army, today sent an unmistakable warning in the direction of Poland and her guarantor nations that the "old Prussian land of East Prussia" is German territory and the Reich is able, if necessary, to give military backing to these claims.

HIGHLAND, N.Y., July 20.-- Having cut to the bone the rest of his legislative program for the present session of Congress, President Roosevelt arrived here late tonight and went directly to his family home at Hyde Park, N.Y., to pass a quiet week-end in relaxation after a strenuous fortnight's struggle with the Senate over the neutrality issue.

CINCINNATI, July 20.--The convention of the National Retail Hardware Association was told today that if all retailers would use "a liberal percentage of their gross sales for advertising we would soon see a great improvement in general business conditions as well as greater individual prosperity for the advertiser."

The life of Professor Edwin R.A. Seligman, economist, who died Tuesday at Lake Placid, N.Y., at the age of 78, was eulogized yesterday at simple funeral services in the home of his son, Eustace Seligman, 126 East Seventy-fourth Street, where 200 friends and associates gathered to pay their last respects.

WASHINGTON, July 20.--Elmer T. Andrews, Federal Wage-Hour Administrator, stated at a press conference today that he was now opposed to exempting "white-collar workers" earning $200 or more a month from the provisions of the law.

After ordering the two restaurants in the Cuban Village in the amusement zone at the World's Fair closed yesterday morning because of violations of the sanitary code, Dr. John Grimley, special deputy health commissioner, rescinded the order at 6 P.M., when a second inspection disclosed that the restaurants had corrected the violations.

The report of the United Aircraft Corporation for the six months to June 30, issued for publication today by Donald L. Brown, president, discloses a net profit of $3,678,690 after provision for Federal income taxes at 19 per cent of taxable net income, less credit of 2 per cent of dividend paid.

WASHINGTON, July 20.--Renewed efforts to enact legislation requiring more specific labeling of woolen products occupied the Senate today as Senator Schwartz led a fight for passage of a "truth-infabrics" bill similar to a measure adopted by the Senate in the last session but not acted upon by the House.

ROME, July 20.--The large estates of Sicily, which from time immemorial have made that island poor and uncultivated, will be broken up, the land irrigated, houses, villages and roads built and the population eventually doubled. This was the historic decision announced by Premier Mussolini today to Sicily's fascist leaders.

The automobile and the modern road which it brought in its train were hailed last night as potent means for advancing good-will among the nations by spokesmen for representatives of more than sixty foreign countries who were guests at a dinner of the Ford Motor Company at its pavilion in the World's Fair.

WASHINGTON, July 20.--The Federal Power Commission held today in a precedent-setting decision that it had jurisdiction over an electric utility whose physical lines were located wholly in one State but whose lines comprised part of the pathway by which electricity was transmitted in both directions across State lines.

Fulton Street in Brooklyn offers a major opportunity for replanning and rebuilding to make it one of the "model streets" of the city so far as sound and unified growth are concerned, according to the Mayor's committee on property improvement.

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP).--Calexico, under a brilliant ride by Johnny Longden, overtook Up the Creek in a furious stretch duel today to take Arlington Park's featured fifth race by a head. Risenfly was third.

The elimination of Bob Peacock, University of California ace in the quarter-finals of the Eastern claycourt singles tennis championship at the Jackson Heights Tennis Club yesterday reduced the number of seeded players left in the tournament to two.

Magistrate Francis X. Giaccone in Bridge Plaza Court, Brooklyn, yesterday characterized as a "cheap political gesture" the criticism directed at him last week by County Judge John J. Fitzgerald for holding two 16-year-old boys for arraignment on burglary and petit larceny charges.

WASHINGTON, July 20.--The National Association of Securities Dealers, Inc., filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission the first application for registration under the Maloney amendment to the securities act.

LONDON, July 20.--The British Treasury seemed today to be winning its stubborn battle to control the spending of the 5,000,000 cash loan that had been promised to Poland, in addition to big credits, for the purchase of armaments and war materials.

Less than two weeks after the marriage of Raymond Massey, stage and screen star, to the former wife of William Dwight Whitney, New York lawyer, word from London told yesterday of the marriage of the former Mrs. Massey to Mr. Whitney.

HOBOKEN, N.J., July 20 (AP).-- With actions as quick as the scurrying of the 200 spiders she supervises, Miss Mary Pfeifer began her fifty-first year today as a winder of the gossamer threads spun by her charges.

Despite predictions by national officers of the Workers Alliance that 500,000 WPA workers would quit their jobs yesterday in protest against provisions of the new Federal Relief Act, a survey last night indicated that substantially less than 10 per cent of that number took part in the one-day stoppage.

THE moralists could make a copy-book story of the career of Bucky Walters of the Cin cinnati Reds, who is currently just about the best pitcher in the National League. He's one of the strive-and-succeed school. Nothing but hard work and deep determination put him where he is.

CHICAGO, July 20.--The search of medical scientists for the source of influenza epidemics has turned to hogs and earthworms, and leaders in this field of research may be approaching a discovery of the cause of this scourge, according to The Journal of the American Medical Association.

HONOLULU, July 20 (AP).--While judges at the finish maintained an almost sleepless vigil and observation planes scanned the sea lanes for stray sails, the winner of the 2,085-mile San Francisco-to-Honolulu yacht race remained in doubt today.
Gregor Ziemer, until recently the headmaster of the American School in Berlin, returned yesterday on the United States liner Manhattan accompanied by his wife and 12-yearold daughter Patsy.

CHICAGO, July 20.--The world's grain markets were on the downgrade again today and at no time did they show a disposition to rally. Stop loss orders were uncovered on the way down and closing trades were near the bottom levels. Wheat futures on the Board of Trade here...

A visualization of the World's Fair as a "denial to pessimists who believe that the world is marching toward catastrophe and that today men are only preparing calamities" was made yesterday by Demitrios Sicilianos, Minister of Greece, during exercises in the Fair's Court of Peace as the climax of the celebration of Hellenic Day at the Fair.

MEXICO CITY, July 20.--According to reports that are widespread today throughout Mexico City, negotiations between the Mexican Government and the oil interests for a settlement of the dispute arising from Mexico's seizure of oil lands have now reached a deadlock from which few persons seem to expect them to issue.

LONDON, July 20.--President Roosevelt tonight sent to the Evian Inter-Government Refugee Committee a message expressing his "earnest hope" that the sessions of the committee here "will result in constructive preparation for a speedy alleviation of the terrible plight of those peoples whom we have been striving to assist."

EASTERN POINT, Conn., July 20 (AP).--Eddie Foy, member of last year's Holy Cross freshman football team, demonstrated his skill as a golfer today by firing a two-underpar 70 to lead the qualifiers in the twentieth annual Shenecossett men's invitation tournament.

Al Leach of Cleveland, defending champion, will tee off in the No. 148 position, according to the starting times announced yesterday by the United States Golf Association for the eighteenth annual amateur public links championship which begins next Monday on the Mount Pleasant course in Baltimore. The competition will run through July 29.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 20 (AP).-- Miss Patty Berg probably lost her women's national golf title today-- in a two-hour argument far from a golf course.

CLEVELAND, July 23 (AP).--The Indians batted out a double victory over the Senators today, producing two runs in the final inning of their second contest for a 4-to-3 victory after taking the opener, 11 to 2, behind Bob Feller's effective hurling.

WASHINGTON, July 23.--Secretary Morgenthau announced today that the Treasury, on behalf of the Commodity Credit Corporation, would tomorrow offer through the Federal Reserve Banks $200,000,000 of two-year 5/8 per cent notes of Series D, due Aug. 1, 1941.

Twenty or more years ago cocky little August Wilmont, who stood 2 feet 8 inches in his stocking feet, always bought his clothes at the best tailors and lived in the swankiest theatrical boarding houses. Among the midgets he was known as the King and his brother and partner as the Prince.

An 80-year-old inmate of the Home of the Daughters of Jacob, 167th Street and Findlay Avenue, the Bronx, dangled by a leg high above the rooftops of near-by tenements yesterday, but was rescued with only a leg injury by the combined efforts of policemen, firemen, physicians, nurses and friends.

Twenty-three assistantships and twenty-six scholarships have been awarded for the coming scholastic year in the Fordham University Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, it was announced yesterday, by the Rev. Gustave Dumas, dean of the school.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP).--Strengthening his position as golf's No. 1 man of the year, slender Byron Nelson of Reading, Pa., tools the Western open championship today with a, seventy-two-hole total of 281 strokes--two under par--over the hazard-strewn Medinah Country Club No. 3 course.

The proposed abandonment by the New Haven Railroad of all its lines southeast of Boston out to Cape Cod brings home the change that has taken place in the nation's transportation picture during the past quarter century. The New Haven is the third Eastern railroad to be faced with the problem...

They played one game with the yellow ball and another with the regular white one at Ebbets Field yesterday, but both contests might as well have been waged with a black ball, so far as the Dodgers were concerned.

Reports from sources close to Mayor La Guardia that he planned to become an independent candidate for chief judge of the Court of Appeals this Fall, to succeed Chief Judge Frederick E. Crane who retires at the end of the year by reason of the 70-year age limit, took political observers by surprise last night.

INWOOD, L.I., July 23.--It was a house divided against itself today in the final round of the Inwood Club's member-guest tourney, first event of consequence held here since the 1923 national open championship when Bobby Jones started his string of golfing successes.

The first church for RumanianAmericans in New York, in a fourstory brownstone building at 50 West Eighty-ninth Street, was consecrated yesterday as the Rumanian Orthodox Church of St. Dumitru, named for the patron saint of Rumanian High Commissioner to the World's Fair, Dumitru Gusti.

LONDON, July 23.--The financial markets continue to be altogether politically minded, drifting up or down in consonance with every variation in the news, views or rumors on European and Far Eastern affair's. In endeavoring to present a cheerful front, however, they are only in part successful.

WASHINGTON, July 23.--The Federal Bureau of Investigation today revealed a striking increase in what it described as "the growing menace of espionage."

Reuben Fine made it five straight yesterday to maintain his lead for the championship of the American Chess Federation. In the fourth round at the Hotel George Washington, Fine's opponent was Boris Blumin of Montreal, whom he defeated in thirty-six moves after trapping a knight.

JERSUALEM, July 23.--A Bedouin woman informed searchers today that she knew the whereabout of the Rev. Gerould A.R. Goldner, 29-year-old American missionary, who was kidnapped five days ago by Arab bandits.

A troubled mother we know just called in pitiable distress to tell about the weird psychological problem that has come into her life out of the World of Tomorrow. One night last week she kept her son David, who is 6, up past his normal bed time and stayed long enough on Fiddle-faddle Flats to take in the Lagoon display of fire, water and sound.

WASHINGTON, July 23.--In celebration of the thirtieth anniversary of the army's purchase of its first airplane, one built by the Wright brothers, fleets of war planes will take off simultaneously on Aug. 2 from Air Corps posts throughout the country and fly over cities, the Air Corps announced today. The planes will rise at a signal from the War Department's offices here.

BOSTON, July 23 (AP).--Lou Fette hurled his sixth shut-out of the season today as the Bees triumphed, 1 to 0, over the Pirates in the second game of a double-header, the result of which dropped Pittsburgh from third to fourth place. The Pirates took the opener, 3 to 2, in another pitchers' battle which stopped the veteran Chuck Klein's hitting streak.

PITTSBURGH, July 23.--Reflecting the sharp gain in the volume of steel orders in the previous week, ingot production throughout the country last week advanced 6 points to 56 per cent of capacity, the highest level reached this year, and a point above the previous...

MOSCOW, July 23.--Residents who understand the Czech language have been interested to hear almost every night recently radio broadcasts in that language which almost certainly originate on Soviet soil and are intended for the inhabitants of former Czecho-Slovakia.

IT takes time for stories to drift up this way from Australia, and it was only yesterday that this observer learned the result of "The Stawell Gift," which is an annual affair for the fast of foot held at a place named Stawell, about 125 miles WNW of Melbourne in Australia.

MONTAUK, L.I., July 23.--Elliott Roosevelt has returned from New London, Conn., and is fishing off Montauk Point on the Parrot with Paul Sanborn of Boston and Miami Beach. F. Trubee Davison has arrived from Oyster Bay on his yacht Hurricane. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney is here on his Wanderer.

LONDON, July 14.--The Export Credits Guarantee Department of the Board of Trade during the first half of this year guaranteed to British exporters the payment for roughly $151,800,000 worth of British goods sold abroad on credit.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., July 23.-- Robert Mardfin and Paul Pedersen captured the Leewood invitation tournament trophy today by defeating the team of William F. Zentler and Frank W. Price in the 36-hole final.

CHICAGO, July 23.--Highly beneficial rains fell over part of the main corn belt last week, but there was little or no precipitation in Oklahoma, Kansas and a large area in Nebraska, with the result that further deterioration is reported in the affected areas. KEYPORT, N.J., July 23.--An airplane with two occupants crashed on heavily traveled Route 36 and burst into flame this evening, grazing a parked automobile and missing by seconds two other cars that had passed in opposite directions at the point the plane landed.

A serious breach among the major amusement crafts of the American Federation of Labor appeared probable last night after William Green, A.F. of L. president, refused to acknowledge or deny that the American Federation of Actors, headed by Sophie Tucker, was no longer an A.F. of L. affiliate.

PRAGUE, July 23.--Prince Alexander of Thurn and Taxis, Knight of the Grand Order of Malta, who was Privy Councilor and Chamberlain to the late Emperor Franz Josef of Austria-Hungary, died on Friday in his castle at Louchen, Bohemia, at the age of 88.

NORTHPORT, L.I., July 23.-- George Schrafft, youthful Harvard student from Newton, Mass., and national champion in the 225-cubicinch hydroplane class, climbed another rung up the 1939 title ladder today when he annexed class honors in the Northport Yacht Club's second annual inboard regatta in Northport Harbor.

The Rev. Robert E. Woods, preaching yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, called upon all wealthy persons to read the Gospel of St. Luke, xvi Chapter, and administer their riches according to its precepts.

The Court of Peace at the World's Fair was everything but peaceful yesterday when teams from the Fire Department and Police Department pummeled, pushed and pulled one another all over the area for an hour in what were scheduled as two friendly matches of pushball and tug of war.

A barrage of advertising copy on men's wear will get under way next week, as stores finally start their delayed clearances of Summer goods, according to retail executives. In ordinary years, clearance sales have begun immediately after July 4, but this season the unusually...

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 23.--In the first test of the year holding possible Davis Cup implications, Adrian Quist of Australia administered a crushing defeat to Gene Mako of Los Angeles today to become the first foreign player to win the Longwood Bowl since his fellow countryman, Gerald Patterson, triumphed here in 1925.

Development of a new "electric fan" airplane propeller with four blades, the first hint of which was given by the army several weeks ago, was announced yesterday by the Curtiss Propeller Division of Curtiss-Wright Corporation. The company said it would soon start production of the new propeller at its Clifton, N.J., plant.

What is believed to be the first "goggle" fishing tournament (one of Aycock Brown's ideas) ever held in this country, will be conducted on Aug. 4 at Beaufort, N.C. Goggle, for those unfamiliar with this sport, is a term, not a species.

NEW ORLEANS, July 23.--Governor Earl K. Long's announcement that he had chosen Earle Christenberry, former secretary to his brother, Huey P. Long, to fill the same post for him, caused politicians here today to wonder whether the cult of "Share Our Wealth" was to be revived in Louisiana.
An increasingly serious view of the drought that has parched the North Atlantic States and some Western areas was put forward yesterday by the New Jersey State Department of Agriculture.

Buying proceeded at an active pace in the apparel and accessories markets last week, and piece goods were bought in good quantities. The costume suit in fur-jacket, long-coat and four-way effects continued to lead on dress purchases, while there was increased interest in silk dresses and back-to-school wool frocks.
URBANA, Ill., July 23.--Dot photography, a new kind of X-ray picture, was announced today at the University of Illinois.

Her eyes glistening with tears of joy, Mrs. Ida Harris, a 65-year-old newspaper vendor whose stand has occupied the corner of Wall and William Streets for twenty years, stoked in the bright sun of the Sculptors Outdoor Summer Show yesterday afternoon and watched Adolf Wolff fashion her head in clay.

With business news at hand--news of a nature that could not be ignored-the stock market, with but two pauses, pushed forward last week to the best levels since March 13. It was an impressive show of bullish force that not even a pessimistic statement by the President on the future course of business could pull down.
WESTSURY, L.I., July 23.--Today's games in the national twentygoal polo championship furnished surprises, one of them in the winner and the other in the size of the score.
BAR HARBOR, Me., July 23.-- General and Mrs. J. William Kilbreth of New York entertained at the Bar Harbor Club buffet supper tonight for Mrs. Edgar T. Appleby, their house guest.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 23.-- Dr. Joseph Thomas Welch Sr., a practicing physician in this city for thirty-nine years and well known in fraternal circles, died early today at his home here at the age of 72. He was dean of the medical profession of this city and had been city physician for the last eight years.

WASHINGTON, July 23.--With the Administration's lending bill as the major obstacle to early adjournment, both houses of Congress will drive during the coming week to clear the last legislative slate for the session with the hope of an ending some time before Aug. 5.

TOKYO, Monday, July 24.--Having overcome the difficulty of reaching a common formula, British and Japanese representatives this morning opened their conference for a solution of the Tientsin problem. Good hopes were expressed on both sides for a solution before the end of the month.
ANGORA, Turkey, July 23 (AP).-- Rejoicing Turks today began a three-day national holiday to mark the return of the Republic of Hatay from Syria to Turkey.

LONDON, July 23.--A sensation was created in London tonight by the disclosure that Robert S. Hudson, energetic Secretary of the Department of Overseas Trade, had discussed a far-reaching peace settlement, including a huge loan with a representative of the German Government last week.

NEWARK, N.J., July 23 (AP).-- Before a crowd of 14,186, the Bears went on a slugging spree and handed the league-leading Jersey City Giants a double defeat, taking the opener, 11-3, and the nightcap, 8 to 6. It was the sixth consecutive Sunday twin bill Newark has captured.

GLACIER, Wash., July 23.--A half mile long snowslide which apparently claimed the lives of six members of a college scaling party yesterday on steep-sloped Mount Baker, gave up the bodies of two of the victims today.

Peter C. Spence, former head of the Fire Prevention Bureau of the Fire Department and of a similar bureau in the Building Department, Borough of Manhattan, died yesterday at his home, 70 West Seventyfirst Street, after an illness of two months. He was 66 years old.

CHICAGO, July 24.--The formation of a centralized agency to combat by educational means all forms of socialism in Federal and local governments was announced here today by officials of the Transportation Association of America, whose membership is comprised of national business and industrial leaders.
WASHINGTON, July 24.--In the Hatch bill, Vice President Garner has contrived such a double-action trap for President Roosevelt as has rarely been seen in American politics.

TRIESTE, Italy, July 24.--If Germany is preparing to take over Trieste or a substantial part of it in the near future and establish here shipbuilding yards and submarine stations and even an air base there is no physical indication of such a development at present.

Orders booked by furniture manufacturers in the first half of this year were 25 per cent greater than in the corresponding period last year, Seidman Seidman, public accountants specializing in the furniture industry, reported yesterday.

E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. announced yesterday that the board of directors now had under consideration a plan whereby the holders of $109,294,800 of $100 par 6 per cent debenture stock now outstanding would have an opportunity to exchange their shares for preferred stock on a basis yet to be determined.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass., July 24.--Mrs. James A. Renwick of Ledgewood, Hillsdale, N.Y., was a luncheon hostess today on the Colonial Terrace at the Berkshire Inn, here, for Mrs. George L. Taylor and Mrs. Clark T. Durant.

CHICAGO, July 24.--Texas Christian's little quarterback, Davey O'Brien, was stamped tonight as the most highly regarded player in the country by the nation-wide poll to choose a college all-star football squad to play the New York Giants, pro champions, at Soldier Field on the night of Aug. 30.

Some cautious commentators who felt that last year's broad building activity in Queens County, giving it the leading place in the nation, might be only a "flash in the pan" and was too favorable a showing to be continued for a long period are being confounded by the latest reports on work in that borough.

WASHINGTON, July 24.--Desultory interest on the part of the Senate, which has delayed for three years the ratification of a treaty with Panama designed to perfect the original treaty of 1903 governing the rights of the United States in the Canal Zone, resulted in another failure to act late today for lack of a quorum.
WASHINGTON, July 24.--Congressional leaders began applying the lash in dead earnest today in a new effort to adjourn the present session by the middle of next week.

MARION, Mass., July 24.--The opening race in the series for the Roosevelt Bowl for yachts in the thirty square meters class was sailed today off the Beverly Yacht Club, with a fifteen-knot southwester providing plenty of thrills.
WASHINGTON, July 24.--A broad bill by Senator La Follette designed to outlaw "oppressive labor practices" was reported favorably to the Senate calendar today by the Committee on Education and Labor.

PHILADELPHIA, July 24.--Seven Republicans and three Democrats became candidates for Mayor by filing nominating petitions today just before the final "deadline" in anticipation of the Sept. 12 primary election.

MANCHESTER, England, July 24 (Canadian Press).--Spin bowlers took full advantage of a damp wicket at Old Trafford today and at the adjournment England and the West Indies looked to be near a stalemate in the second cricket test match.

BAR HARBOR, Me., July 24.-- Mr. and Mrs. Charles C.G. Chaplin were dinner hosts at La Selva tonight for Mr. and Mrs. Harald Paumgarten, Mr. and Mrs. William Van Alen, Miss Joan Mainwaring and Miss C. Buchanan.

LONDON, July 24.--A brighter tone was evident in the stock markets today, with Wall Street's Saturday rises partly responsible. Also the strong home trade position successfully countered the uncertainty of the international situation. An all-round improvement in home industrials ...

SHANGHAI, July 24 (AP).--Japanese dispatches from Hsinking, Manchukuo, today asserted that 1,000 Soviet Russian-Outer Mongolian troops had crossed the Khalka River into Manchukuoan territory and precipitated heavy fighting with Japanese-Manchukuoan forces.

A final vote will be taken this Saturday by the Cooperative Wholesale Society of England on the opening of limited price variety or "bazaar trading" stores to meet the competition of Woolworth's and Marks Spencer in England, F.H. Webber, member of the board of the Brighton Cooperative Society, said in an interview yesterday.

Active buying marked the opening yesterday of the fifteenth semiannual New York Lamp Show at the Hotel New Yorker. A total of 650 buyers, 10 per cent more than registered on the opening day of the exhibit last July, toured the displays offered by more than 180 producers.

Published reports that Mayor La Guardia might be an independent candidate for Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals this Fall were received with considerable interest, and an equal amount of skepticism, in political circles yesterday.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the Chase National Bank, and Mrs. Aldrich and Mr. and Mrs. Hobart C. Chatfield-Taylor are among the passengers arriving from Europe today on the Cunard White Star liner Mauretania.

Leonard Del Genio, Bronx welterweight contender, scored a knockout over Bobby Masters of Philadelphia in the main bout scheduled for eight rounds last night at the Coney Island Velodrome before 3,000 fans.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 24.-- Ernest Gross, 56 years old, an unemployed plasterer of Fort Lee who has been receiving relief off and on for several years, rebelled when he was told he had to work for his money.

The terms announced yesterday on the Commodity Credit Corporation's $200,000,000 refunding operation, that of 5/8 per cent notes, due in two years, were about in line with market expectations. The reception accorded the issue made substantial oversubscription a foregone conclusion.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 24.--Dr. Robert J. McGuire, a member of the faculty of the College of Medicine, Syracuse University, and a practicing physician, died suddenly of a heart attack late last night at his home here in his fifty-fifth year. He had performed an operation on Saturday and had appeared to be in good health.

Four acting captains of the New York City police force will be promoted to captains, eighteen sergeants will become lieutenants and fifty-six patrolmen will be elevated to sergeants at graduation exercises of 112 recruits from the police academy in Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island at 10:30 A.M. today.

WASHINGTON, July 24.--The $26,500,000 first-mortgage 3 per cent bonds of the Kansas Power and Light Company due in 1969 will be offered to the public on Wednesday at 108 per cent, according to an amendment filed today by the company with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP).--The Department of Agriculture estimated today that there would be a new record supply of wheat in the world's bread basket for the year which began on July 1. It tentatively placed the prospective world supply for 1939-40 at about 5,290000,000 bushels, or about 120,000,000 bushels above the record supplies in the preceding twelve months.

MONTREAL, July 24.--With wheat futures touching record lows, Canadian growers will welcome the news from government sources at Ottawa today that Great Britain will establish a substantial wheat reserve in Canada.

James H. Fay, the sole New Deal victor in the "purge" of 1938, formally announced yesterday his intention of contesting the Tammany leadership of the Twelfth Assembly District South with William P. Kenneally, the chairman of the executive committee of Tammany Hall.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., July 24 (AP). --President and Mrs. Roosevelt signed today a deed transferring to the Federal Government twelve acres of the family estate as the site for a library to house more than 6,000,000 of the Chief Executive's official documents and manuscripts.

MOSCOW, July 24.--The Soviet Government's efforts to "sell" the Soviet people on the necessity and glory of a great Red navy, such as the nation is now feverishly building up, were focused today in a celebration of "Navy Day" in Moscow and Leningrad.

Buyers in numbers said by several producers of millinery to be larger than ever before visited manufacturers' showrooms yesterday as the Fall Market Week sponsored by the Millinery Stabilization Commission, Inc., began.

The first giant tuna of the season taken off the New Jersey shore, and it wasn't much of a giant, was brought in this weekend by Major Aaron Carpenter, who was chumming near Big Rock, located about ten miles off Belmar. The fish was just under 100 pounds.

With virtually all the ranking dignitaries of the Latin-American consular corps in attendance, the 156th anniversary of the birth of General Simon Bolivar was celebrated yesterday at ceremonies sponsored by the Pan-American Society.

The Oranges and Maplewood, N.J., turned out en masse to visit the World's Fair yesterday with thirty busloads of residents of the New Jersey communities going to the exposition to celebrate Oranges and Maplewood Day. Heading their delegation were the Mayors of the various towns.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 24.--The Baptist World Alliance, holding its sixth congress here, heard today from its general secretary, the Rev. Dr. J. H. Rushbrooke of London a plea to combat assaults upon civil and religious freedom in Europe and in Japan.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 24.-- Cotton textile men, brokers and dealers in waste said here today that a government subsidy of 1 cents a pound on raw cotton exports would be of doubtful benefit and expressed fear that it would bring about additional trade and industrial disturbance.

The National Gypsum Company showed a net profit of $696,705 in the first half of this year, after depletion, depreciation, interest and provision for United States and Canadian income taxes, according to the semi-annual statement issued today by Melvin H. Baker, president.

Imports of gold at New York aggregated yesterday $12,651,000, a large part of which, it was understood, represented "official shipments" to go into the stock of the metal set aside here under earmark for foreign account. Of the receipts, $12,646,000 came from England and $5,000 from Guatemala.

ALBANY, July 24.--During June the 118 local offices of the State Employment Service made 24,245 placements, according to a report issued today by Frieda S. Miller, Industrial Commissioner. Of the total, 19,331 jobs were in private industry and 4,914 in public employment, including WPA.

Tisha B'Ab, the ninth day in the Hebrew month of Ab, was observed last night by worshipers in the synagogues of the metropolitan area as a religious fast day commemorating the destruction of the first and second temples in Jerusalem by the Babylonians and Romans.

The two titans in the American chess world, Samuel Reshevsky, the United States champion, and Reubin Fine, famous internationalist, came together in the sixth round of the championship finals of the American Chess Federation at the Hotel George Washington last night.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP).-- Taking part in a radio discussion of the Administration's lending program, Senator Wagner of New York said tonight he was convinced that it would "stimulate a tremendous volume of orders for private industry" and reduce the ranks of the unemployed without increasing the public debt.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP).--The government began court action today to compel compliance with the Federal-State milk marketing program in New York and to collect more than $300,000 owed the producers settlement fund by nearly twoscore handlers.
VIENNA, July 24.--The Vienna municipality has decreed that the entire personal estate and music rights of Johann Strauss 2d are the property of the city.

LONDON, July 24.--A recognition of the "special requirements" of the Japanese Army in China and a certain amount of cooperation with that army have been agreed upon as a formula upon which the British and the Japanese can negotiate a settlement of the Tientsin dispute, Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain told the House of Commons today.

DETROIT, July 24.--Tool and die workers of Fisher Body plant No. 1 in Flint went out today on the twentieth day of the strike of skilled employes of General Motors Corporation, called by the C.I.O. United Automobile Workers of America.

Three odds-on favorites went down to defeat yesterday at Empire City in a day that closed with a heavy shower turning the track sloppy. The first of the disappointments was John Hay Whitney's Wait for Baby, a 9-to-10 favorite that was beaten a head by T.P. Morgan's Wanna Hygro at five and a half furlongs.

WASHINGTON, July 24.--The United States Government views with concern the increasing number of cases of violence against Americans by the Japanese military in China, Secretary of State Cordell Hull said today.

In an effort to direct public attention to the ravages of chronic ailments, such as rheumatism, arthritis, heart disease, nervous disorders and gland troubles and others, a diorama was set in motion at 6 o'clock last night on the balcony at the Grand Central Station.

CHICAGO, July 24 (AP).--The money lure of professional football became too great today for Sid Luckman, Columbia University triple-threat star of last season. Luckman, 194-pound back, signed a two-year contract with the Chicago Bears of the National League.

LONGMANS, GREEN'S "Living Thoughts Library" represents one of the latest and most ambitious of those concatenated projects that our publishers like to undertake from time to time. Edited by Alfred O. Mendel and illustrated with woodcut portraits by Hans Alexander Mueller, the series now numbers eight volumes, one for each of the following: Schopenhauer, Rousseau, Nietzsche, Darwin, Tolstoy, Thoreau, Mazzini and Montaigne.

RUMSON, N.J., July 25.--Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. of Crestmont increased her lead to nine strokes today in the eleventh annual fiftyfour-hole women's metropolitan shore golf tournament. She scored 39, 40--79 on the Rumson links for a total of 153 for thirty-six holes.

BERLIN, July 25.--The entire press today features extensive accounts of German submarine manoeuvres in the Baltic Sea, in which the entire submarine fleet-- reported to number seventy-one craft--participated under the personal supervision of Admiral General Erich Raeder.
"Of Human Bondage" will be revived at Loew's Criterion, beginning today. The film, produced in 1934 by RKO from the Somerset Maugham novel, co-stars Bette Davis and Leslie Howard.

PITTSBURGH, July 25 (AP).--A wild pitch by Relief Hurler Hugh Mulcahy in the tenth inning, with the bases loaded and two out, gave the Pirates two runs and a 5-4 victory over the Phils today. The victory sent Pittsburgh to second place, ahead of the Cardinals, with a percentage of .5244 against St. Louis' .5238.

Steps to put the ticket broker out of business entirely, through the establishment of a producer-controlled central agency, are planned for next Fall by the League of New York Theatres, the organization of producers, it was disclosed yesterday.
