Whittlesey House has signed contracts for a book on acting by Ezekial B. Colvan, general stage director for the Municipal Opera Association, at St. Louis. Titled "Face the Footlights," it will discuss the fundamentals of acting for students and amateurs.

CHUNGKING, China. July 25.-- Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek repudiated the suggestion that Britain had compromised with Japan at the expense of China in a statement on China's wartime position in relation to international support.

WASHINGTON, July 25.--The Administration's $2,490,000,000 Works Financing Bill went before the Senate late today accompanied by an ultimatum from Senator Barkley, the majority leader, that Congress would not be permitted to adjourn until this measure had been disposed of "one way or the other."

The first two full months' operation of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge indicates that it is not cutting into traffic seriously on the Triborough Bridge and that the combined traffic of the two bridges will exceed engineers' advance estimates, it was disclosed yesterday when the semi-annual report of the Triborough Bridge Authority was made public.

SHERMAN, Me., July 25.--Using nature lore he learned as a Boy Scout, 12-year-old Donn Fendler of Rye, N.Y., emerged today exhausted and almost naked from the Mount Katahdin wilderness in which he had wandered for eight days while the object of one of Maine's greatest searches.

Bonds worked irregularly higher in more active trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. The market was a rather selective affair, however, with special issues and groups attracting most speculative attention while the general market drifted aimlessly about with little following. The trading pace was stepped up to a turnover of $7,352,200, compared with $4,889,000 on Monday.

WASHINGTON, July 25.--Coastwise steamship lines operating between North Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico ports told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that granting of an application by Seatrain Lines, Inc., for joint rates with railroads no higher than those of competing break-bulk coastwise steamship lines would mean the "death knell" of the latter.

Apparently the victim of mistaken identity, Irving Penn, 42 years old, head of the royalties and publications department of G. Schirmer, Inc., music publishers, was shot and killed yesterday morning as he walked from his home toward the Eighth Avenue subway on his way to work.

CHICAGO, July 25 (AP).--The name of Comiskey--which for two generations helped build the sport--will continue in baseball.

James Barton, who in February withdrew as the star of "Tobacco Road" after a backstage tiff which ultimately resulted in Actors Equity reprimanding him for using abusive language, has turned in his notice again, effective Aug. 26.
WASHINGTON, July 25.--The proposed amendments to the Wages and Hours Act apparently were part of a tangled legislative situation in the House Rules Committee today.

The stock market failed yesterday to follow through with its strong opening and values were reduced to an irregular closing as the volume dropped off after the initial hour. The day's turnover was 1,229,650 shares, against 1,062,210 shares in the previous session.

East End Avenue, which has been on of the quieter neighborhoods in the East Side residential section in recent years so far as new construction is concerned, is to get another tall multi-family house.

DETROIT, July 25.--P.D. Fitzpatrick, general manager of the Grand Trunk Western Railroad, died here today in a hospital where he was operated upon several weeks ago. He was 59 years old.

WASHINGTON July 25.--United States foreign trade last month was greater both in volume and in value than in June, 1938, with exports showing a slight gain and imports advancing almost 25 per cent, the Department of Commerce announced today. Both exports and imports fell off materially from May.

WASHINGTON, July 25.--Business activity in the United Kingdom has in teased in virtually all branches, the Commerce Department, said today in reviewing reports received by cable and radio from various world centers.

CHICAGO, July 25.--Prices of wheat rallied sharply today in the world's leading markets. Unexpected strength in Liverpool and reports that large amounts of North American cash wheat had been sold for export furnished the basis for short covering which carried prices on the Board of Trade here up 1 cents a bushel from Monday's closing level.

An appreciable increase in the amount of new steamship tonnage to be classified during 1939 by the American Bureau of Shipping was forecast yesterday by J. Lewis Luckenbach, president, in his semiannual report to the board of managers. The board met at 24 Old Slip.

LONDON, July 25.--The complete autograph manuscript of Charles Dickens's "The Life of Our Lord" was purchased after determined bidding for 1,400 by Philip Rosenbach, brother of the American bookseller, Dr. A.S.W. Rosenbach, at Sotheby's auction rooms today.

The census to be made for the British Government of the American and Dutch securities now held by British investment trusts and insurance companies follows upon the unofficial embargo on the purchase of foreign securities established by-the British Government on April 20.

BOSTON, July 25 (AP).--Supported by plenty of home-run slugging, the Red Sox opened their longest home stay of the season today by toppling the hard-pressing White Sox twice, 3--2 and 6--5, before a crowd of 20,000. The second game went ten innings.

DEL MONTE, Calif., July 25.-- The spirit of moral rearmament was demonstrated as a force powerful enough to unite opposing nations and fighting factions within those nations in "a pattern of a new world order" at today's session of the M.R.A. movement's world assembly.

Some 1,500 buyers of millinery from this country and all over the world crowded the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor last night to view new Fall styles put on display under the auspices of the trade promotion committee of the Millinery Stabilization Commission, Inc.

Two important chemical companies reported favorable earnings in their condition statements, the report of the Dow Chemical Company being for the fiscal year ended on May 31, while the Monsanto Chemical Company issued its results for the quarter and six months ended on June 30.

Increases in passenger revenues were reported by the New York Central and Pennsylvania railroads for June, in which period reduced round-trip coach and Pullman rates were in force. The coach rate was cut from 2.5 to 2 cents a mile, return, for 200 miles, with reductions
CHICAGO, July 25.--Sales at the monthly Chicago Shoe Market, closing here today, were about equal to the July, 1938, event, and about 10 per cent under that of June.

A home made streamlined job done in stout wood with wide axles and small rubber tired wheels carried the day yesterday for Robert F. (Bobby) Lane, 14-year-old Brooklyn youngster, in the annual metropolitan Soap Box Derby for boys.

Japan announced a new step against Britain yesterday despite the latter's agreement not to obstruct Japanese army activities in the occupied areas of China. Beginning at midnight tonight the Canton River will be closed to traffic, thus barring commerce from British Hong Kong.

LONDON, July 25.--The British Government is giving active consideration to a proposal to provide Russia with a new and dramatic proof of the genuineness of Britain's desire for an anti-aggression agreement by opening staff talks immediately, it was learned tonight.
Architects submitted to the Department of Housing and Buildings yesterday the details of a number of large projects in Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens.

BALTIMORE, July 25.--Youth was served in the eighteenth national public links golf championship today as four youngsters with an average age of 20 years finished two days and thirty-six holes of golf over the back-breaking Mount Pleasant Park course tied for medal honors with 144 strokes.

CINCINNATI, July 25 (AP).--Harry Craft hit his eighth homer of the season with a man on base in the seventh inning tonight to give Cincinnati a 2-to-1 victory over the Boston Bees before 28,682 fans at Crosley Field. It was Bucky Walters's seventeenth victory of the year and his sixth straight and increased the Reds' National League lead to ten games.

WASHINGTON, July 25.--Japan will be held responsible for any injury to Americans or damage to their property resulting from operations incident to the closing of the river between Canton and Hong Kong, Secretary of State Cordell Hull announced today.

MOUNT WILSON, Calif., July 27. --This morning I observed Mars at 3 A.M. 7 A.M. in New York, just ten hours before the moment of closest approach. WASHINGTON, July 28.--The scientific phases of the government's coming Antarctic expedition were discussed today at a conference under the auspices of the National Academy of Science called by the National Research Council which is its operating agency.

BERLIN, July 28.--The "Sixteenth Great German Radio and Television Exhibition, Berlin, 1939," was opened here this morning by Propaganda Minister Joseph Goebbels. In this vehement period when the Germans are fighting for their rights, the Propaganda Minister said, they stand united behind Chancellor Hitler.

ROCHESTER, Minn., July 28 (AP). --Dr. William J. Mayo, surgeon who with his brother made the name of their clinic known throughout the world, died in his sleep early today of a sub-acute perforating ulcer, an abdominal ailment he had specializad in treating.

LONDON, July 28.--No Ministry of Information will be established in England in peacetime, Sir Samuel Hoare, Home Secretary, told the House of Commons today when discussing the government's request for additional appropriations of 260,000 for putting the British case abroad.

PARIS, July 28.--The prorogation of the present Parliament for a period of two years was reported to have been approved at a Cabinet meeting held this evening at the War Ministry. SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 4 (AP).-- Union truck drivers and operators today signed a new three-year contract, dispelling threats of a strike which would have tied up the State's over-the-road trucking industry.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 17.-- Walter Wanger announced today that he will produce Jules Verne's "Around the World in Eighty Days" on a $2,000,000 budget with filming scheduled for next January. Wanger will seek to obtain Ronald Colman, it was indicated, for the role of Phineas Fogg, leading figure in the story, who wagers $100,000 that he can make a tour of the world in eighty days.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 17.-- As the National Institute for Traffic Safety Training continued its diversified program today, with the University of Michigan as host, names of the seven winners of the 1939 Alfred P. Sloan Jr. traffic safety fellowships were disclosed. The seven were selected by a committee from several hundred applicants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17.--The Federal Government has acquired title to 1,670,000 bales of cotton of 1934 held as collateral for government loans, and will use the cotton to complete the cotton-rubber barter deal with Great Britain. Delivery also will be made on sales to Spain, ...

LANSING, Mich., Aug. 17 (AP).-- Governor Luren D. Dickinson aimed a blow at organized gambling in Michigan today. He ordered virtually the entire State police force of several hundred men to seek evidence of gambling violations, arrest operators of illegal gambling devices and confiscate the equipment.

Three new stockholders' actions have been brought in New York Supreme Court against George W. Hill Jr. and other present and former officials of the American Tobacco Company, it was disclosed yesterday when the defendants moved to consolidate the actions. Justice Thomas F. Noonan reserved decision on the application.

To the long list of America's own royalty we may now add the Onion Queen. She was formally enthroned on Tuesday in Orange Coun ty, N.Y., which sends 2,000,000 bushels of the aromatic root to market. American crowned heads are exclusively female, if memory serves.

MANASSAS, Va., Aug. 17.--The two National Guard Blue Divisions, defending Washington, ended the manoeuvres in this section today by a drive against the Regular Army Black forces which sent them back four miles before an armistice was declared at 11 A.M.

The majority of younger Democrats throughout the United States favor a third term for President Roosevelt despite the fact that that one important question was not put to a vote at the recent convention of the Young Democrats clubs, according to a survey of the American Institute of Public Opinion.

MOSCOW, Aug. 17.--A banquet given by the French Embassy last night in honor of War Commissar Klementy E. MAEHRISCH-OSTRAU, Bohemian-Moravian Protectorate, Aug. 17.--Germany's military preparations in the protectorate are proceeding with great speed and thoroughness. The writer, however, is able to deny most of those rumors that circulated in Prague a few days ago, causing much anxiety in its foreign colony.

The Very Rev. Christopher J. Plunkett, provincial for the United States of the Holy Ghost Fathers, a Catholic missionary order, and founder of the first Catholic Church for Negroes in Harlem, died yesterday afternoon in the Lutheran Hospital after an illness of two days. He was 72 years old.

A century of progress in photography was celebrated at the World's Fair yesterday with the commemoration by the Eastman Kodak Company of the 100th anniversary of the general publication of the photographic process developed by Louis Jacques Daguerre by which the daguerreotype, the great-grandfather of present-day pictures, was made.

Delegates to the biennial State convention of the Ancient Order of Hibernians adopted a resolution opposing the participation of this government in the entanglements of foreign governments at the closing session held yesterday in the Hotel St. George in Brooklyn.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 17.--Representative Hamilton Fish of New York today addressed the Interparliamentary Union Congress, stressing that he spoke only for himself and not on behalf of the United States Government but adding, "but I do not believe that any American will oppose my proposal. I am isolationist as regards war, but nonisolationist as regards peace."

William F.X. Geoghan, Kings County District Attorney, testifying for the second day at the bribery trial of his assistant, Alexander R. Baldwin, admitted yesterday that he had received the undated resignation of Baldwin last year.

The Automobile Manufacturers Association, adviser and spokesman for twenty-eight of America's thirty leading passenger car and truck makers, will move its headquarters from New York City to Detroit between now and Jan. 1, it was learned yesterday.

William F.X. Geoghan, Kings County District Attorney, testifying for the second day at the bribery trial of his assistant, Alexander R. Baldwin, admitted yesterday that he had received the undated resignation of Baldwin last year.

The Automobile Manufacturers Association, adviser and spokesman for twenty-eight of America's thirty leading passenger car and truck makers, will move its headquarters from New York City to Detroit between now and Jan. 1, it was learned yesterday.

NUTLEY, N.J., Aug. 17.--Ted Turner of Pine Valley, 1938 champion, tied with Mike Cestone, Montclair letter carrier, and Andy La Pola, Preakness Hills professional, at the end of the first round today in the New Jersey State open golf championship at the Yountakah Country Club. The trio equaled par of 72.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17.--Perfection of a new weather instrument so delicate that it can measure the temperature of drops of water a mile above the earth is announced by the American Meteorological Society.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 17.-- Emil Mosbacher Jr. and his Knickerbocker Yacht Club mates became the Long Island Sound junior sailing champions and broke the Pequot Yacht Club's three-year hold on the Pequot Cup today when the series conducted by Pequot came to an end to the relief of all hands.

With their first group of buildings nearing completion on Main Street and Union Turnpike, in Kew Gardens, L.I., to house 540 families, Anthony and Thomas Morell announced plans yesterday to expand this extensive apartment center to provide eventually nearly 2,500 suites.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Aug. 17. --A serious incident took place today on the Hungarian frontier near Ateiashulnou near Salonta Transylvania, when a Rumanian frontier patrol was attacked while making its rounds. Several shots were fired, one soldier was shot dead, a sergeant was bayoneted ...

MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 17.-- The pace among players preparing for the national polo championship quickened a bit today when Tommy Hitchcock led a Greentree combination to victory over a Roslyn side at Jock Whitney's estate, 12 to 10.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 17.--The redhot Red Birds of St. Louis handed the Pirates their ninth consecutive defeat today, 4 to 2, as the Cardinals fought their way to their fourth straight victory and the sixteenth in their last eighteen starts.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 17.-- North Shore society braved the excessive heat and humidity to provide a crowded gallery on the grounds of the Old Field Club for the opening session of the tenth annual North Shore horse show today.

The new Panama Railroad liner Cristobal, a $4,000,000 passengercargo liner specially designed for the coastwise run to the Canal Zone, sailed on her maiden voyage yesterday with nearly 200 passengers. The Cristobal is the third of three sister ships constructed for the line at Quincy, Mass.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, Aug. 17.--Winning for the fourth time in as many starts, Salo Flohr of Prague took sole possession of first place in the international masters tournament at the congress of the British Chess Federation today when he defeated W.S. Wallis of London in 30 moves.

NEWARK, Aug. 17.--Two proposals made by the Associated Wineries of New Jersey, Inc., and others for a change in New Jersey regulations for bottling and decanting wine were opposed here today at a hearing before Maurice E. Ash, senior inspector for the State Department ...

John M. Kantor, 60 years old, who, in December, 1938, was questioned in the Federal investigation of the alleged looting of the McKesson Robbins drug concern by the Musica brothers, again was arrested yesterday as a swindler.

A conspiracy by which five WPA timekeepers made it possible for twelve WPA workers to continue collecting salaries after they had left to take private jobs was charged in an indictment handed up yesterday by a Federal grand jury. All seventeen of the men involved were named in the indictment.

Officials of the World's Fair Corporation announced last night that a new retrenchment program put into effect this week had cut the Fair's payroll about $1,000 a day, and that operating expenses had been reduced between $4,500 and $5,000 a day by means of dismissals, resignations and other economies since the wholesale dismissals and salary cuts for executives put into effect for the July 20 budget.

With New York City beginning to feel the pinch of the milk strike in thirty up-State counties and with fresh outbreaks of violence and more plants being closed in the strike area, Governor Lehman ordered all available State Troopers on duty yesterday to deal with a strike situation that was described by State Agriculture Commissioner Holton V. Noyes as "very serious."

BOSTON, Aug. 17 (AP).--The death today of the Rev. Dr. Cornelius H. Patton of West Hartford, Conn., at his Waterville Valley, N.H., Summer home, was reported today by the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions. He was 78 years old.
IT was a great relief to the tennis authorities when the Yugoslav Davis Cup team arrived on these shores the other day intact and sound in wind and limb.
STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 18. --Miss Deborah G. Rood of Wilmington, Del., who entered a string of six hunters in the tenth annual North Shore horse show, had more success with other folks' horses ...
Leonard Hartman, local tennis star, who tops the ranking players remaining in the tournament, advanced to the semi-final round of the national public parks championship yesterday at Randalls Island.

Broadway traffic at Fiftieth Street was halted for about ten minutes and impeded for about twenty more minutes shortly after 4:30 P.M. yesterday when fire started in a duct leading from the kitchen range in the basement of Lindy's Restaurant, 1,626 Broadway, one door south of Fiftieth Street.

SAN SEBASTIAN, Spain, Aug. 18.--Nationalist Spain is planning to send some of her crack airmen on a flight to South America within the next few weeks, it was learned today. The project will have the twofold objective of reasserting Spain's cultural leadership in her former colonies and of surveying a route for an air-mail service.

Mr. and Mrs. Horace G. Reed of 46 East Eighty-first Street will give a dinner dance on Christmas night on the St. Regis Roof to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Rosamund Reed. Mr. and Mrs. Reed and the members of their family are at Windymoor, their place on Tuckernuck Island, Nantucket, Mass.
LONDON, Aug. 18 (Canadian Press).--Two of the most exciting finishes in English cricket this season thrilled spectators at Cheltenham and Southend today.

Below, boldface numbers in parenthesis refer to white numbers in black circles on map to the right, and show where events take place. Where numerals are not given, notations refer to key around the map.

TOKYO, Saturday, Aug. 19.-- Britain's decision to rule out any bilateral discussion of Tientsin's economic issues is received by the press with an outburst of anger and a warning that it means the immediate rupture of the negotiations.

The directors of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith in the more than 100 Roman Catholic dioceses of the United States will hold their fifth national convention in the Hotel Commodore Aug. 28-30.

Stanley Fisher of Forest Hills won the World's Fair archery championship yesterday. Miss Ann Weber of Bloomfield, N.J., took the women's title and Miss Laura Quinn of Woodbridge, N.J., the junior laurels in the tournament conducted by the National Archery Association in Flushing Meadows.

CHUNGKING, China, Aug. 18.-- Wang Ching-wei's efforts to promote a separatist movement in South China has met little or no support from leaders in the Chinesecontrolled areas of South China Provinces.
CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP).--The White Sox got only three hits off Bobby Feller tonight but squeezed across a run in the eleventh inning to defeat the Indians, 1 to 0, before 46,000 spectators.

New bond issues aggregating $92,840,444 were placed on the market this week, including the $32,000,000 financing offered yesterday afternoon for the Central Power and Light Company bonds and debentures. The total compares with last week's volume of $165,240,000 which was the largest of any week since that ended June 3, 1938.

CONISTON, England, Aug. 18 (AP).--Sir Malcolm Campbell and his latest Bluebird skimmed over Lake Coniston today at a record-breaking speed of 134 miles an hour in "just a warm-up" for an effort to kite the water speed mark to about 150 miles an hour.
Plans have been completed for the wedding of Miss Alice Noel Rutgers and Anthony Drexel Duke, which will take place on Sept. 9 in St. George's-by-the-River, Rumson, N.J.

DALLAS, Texas, Aug. 18 (AP).-- Federal Judge T.W. Davidson released on a writ of habeas corpus today Freeman W. Burford of Dallas, indicted in Louisiana on charges of conspiracy to violate the Connally "Hot Oil" Act, then caustically criticized conditions in that State.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 18.--General Juan Andreu Almazan, principal Opposition candidate for the Presidency, pressed by various newspapers to give an opinion on the oil controversy, has issued a statement declaring it is the duty of all patriotic Mexicans to support their government.

Retail trade results here this week showed sharp variations among stores when compared with a year ago. Store executives attributed this to the fact that the showings last year were spotty. Some stores this week ran even or slightly ahead of last year, when they had heavy sales, while others showed ...
The unusual sight of a tiny child directing a symphonic ensemble drew many of last night's visitors to the World's Fair to the Court of Peace.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18.--The story of aviation export business growth was told in figures today by the Department of Commerce, which said shipments abroad since 1911 through June 30 of this year were valued at $297,778,314.

OSLO, Norway, Aug. 18.--A resolution urging settlement of international differences by peaceful means, based on proposals made by Representative Hamilton Fish of New York, was adopted today by the council of the Interparliamentary Union.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18.--Sales by department stores during the week ended Aug. 12 were 6 per cent more than for the corresponding week in 1938 and in the four-week period ended Aug. 12 rose 5 per cent above the similar period last year, the Federal Reserve Board announced today. For the week ended Aug. 5 the gain was 9 per cent.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 18.--The executive council of the American Federation of Labor today suspended the International Typographical Union, one of the founders of the federation, for failure to pay the special assessment levied more than two years ago to fight the C.I.O. in a militant organization campaign.

The Public Service Commission was petitioned yesterday by eight civic organizations of the Bronx to require the New York Telephone Company to make all phone calls within the city limits 5 cents for the first five minutes.

Theatregoers of the season of 1933-34 will no doubt remember "Mary of Scotland" and more particularly the team of Helen Hayes and Philip Merivale. As events stand this morning, Miss Hayes and Mr. Merivale will be reunited this Fall.

SATAROGA, N.Y., Aug. 18 (AP). --Although thirty-four future racers from the Old Hickory Farm of the noted breeder, Phil T. Chinn, were among fifty-seven head sold in the yearling sales paddock tonight, bidding was quiet with a few exceptions.

Governor A.B. (Happy) Chandler of Kentucky said yesterday that he would support the Democratic Presidential candidate in 1940 no matter who he might be, even should President Roosevelt be the nominee for a third term.
BOURNEMOUTH, England, Aug. 18.--A change in the leadership took place today in the international masters' tournament at the Congress of the British Chess Federation, which went into the fifth round.

BERLIN, Aug. 18.--Employment figures for old Reich territory continued to climb last month and for the first time passed the 22,000,000 mark. An increase of 175,000 in workers gainfully employed brought the total to 22,050,000 for July. Last year's increase for the same period was 178,000.

Mr. and Mrs. George Cornelius Reid Grandy of Washington, Conn., and Winter Haven, Fla., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Reid Grandy to John Alexander Edwards, son of Mrs. Duncan Edwards of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Edwards.
Their eyes wide with astonishment and joy, 400 of New York City's crippled and handicapped children yesterday marveled at the World of Tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP).--The Red Sox, behind Fritz Ostermueller, defeated the Senators today, 6 to 2. The Boston left-hander had a shutout until the eighth when, with two out, Bobby Estalello scored George Case with a single.

The long heat wave, continuing with no indication of a break, brought yesterday a maximum thermometer reading of 87 degrees and humidity that ranged between 60 and 85 per cent of saturation, averaging 70 per cent.

PARIS, Aug. 18.--France's military aviation program now calls for 8,000 first-class planes, and if need be they will be produced at the rate of 750 monthly under the new "speed-up plan" worked out by Air Minister Guy La Chambre.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 18. --Mr. and Mrs. Pierre Lorillard gave a large dinner tonight at Eden Cottage, their place on the ocean, for Mrs. Lorillard's brother-in-law and sister, Dr. and Mrs. Egil Boeckmann of St. Paul, Minn., who are visiting Mr. and Mrs. Erasmus C. Lindley at their home here.

After a week of confusion over the European situation, traders in securities took yesterday a decidedly pessimistic view of the entire international picture, and a selling wave of large proportions broke over the stock market after midday, forcing prices to the lowest levels in more than a month.

Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange were held within narrow limits yesterday by conflicting factors, and ended with gains of 2 to 5 points. An unsettiing European situation and weakness in the stock market were offset by further heavy rains in central and eastern sections of the cotton belt where not wanted.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18.--Admiral Harry Ervin Yarnell, newest in America's galaxy of naval heroes, came ashore in San Francisco today to rove the seas no more.

HONG KONG, China, Aug. 18.-- Russian air assistance for China, which for a time last year enabled the Chinese to contest Japanese air supremacy in vital sectors, was reported today to have been resumed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18.--Short sales in round lots on the New York Stock Exchange in the week ended on July 29 were 165,370 shares, of which 142,770 shares were for the account of members, and included transactions by specialists for member account, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced today.
BOSTON, Aug. 18.--Competition may be the life of baseball, but the Dodgers and Bees are carrying the thing too far.

LONDON, Aug. 18.--In London the new Reich military agreement with Slovakia is variously described in headlines as "New Hitler coup that sidetracks Danzig," and an instrument by which the "Reich has now gained its third 'protectorate.'"

Large crowds are expected to visit the World's Fair today and tomorrow on the third week-end during which the new 50-cent general admission price is in effect. Fairgoers will find lower prices all along the line.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP).-- Secretary Wallace today offered to wheat growers government payments of 18 to 22 cents a bushel on their 1940 crop if they comply with the agricultural program's acreage limitations. This year's payments are about 22 cents a bushel.

LONDON, Aug. 18.--English and Welsh cooperative retail societies, by a majority of 145 votes, have accepted the proposals of the board of the English Cooperative Wholesale Society for the establishment and operation of national chain limited price variety stores with dollar and quarter price limit. SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18.-- Offers up to $10,000 were made for affidavits linking Harry Bridges with communism, according to a statement ascribed to John L. Leech which was read into the record at the Bridges deportation hearing today.
ROME, Aug. 18.--Rome has lived through a day of intense but vain diplomatic efforts, and it is clear that Europe has now entered a crisis period as acute as last September's.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18.--The American Federation of Labor called upon the government today to start a cooperative effort to spur recovery, and held out to business and industry the threat of new Federal spending-lending legislation unless there was an upturn in business and employment.

LONDON, Aug. 18.--In the Berlin correspondence tonight of The Times, London, it is suggested that Chancellor Hitler's plan for a settlement of the Danzig question may be put into effect within the next few days.

ABOARD U.S.S. LANG, BAY OF ISLANDS, Nfld., Aug. 18 (AP) (By Wireless).--President Roosevelt went fishing for salmon in Humber River Gorge today, but the only catch was made by his military aide, Brig. General Edwin M. Watson.

In the Brooklyn deals reported yesterday, a group of five two-story dwellings in the vicinity of Kings County Hospital were sold to five individuals by the trustee of a mortgage certificate issue. In these transactions, as well as in another which involved three buildings in downtown Brooklyn, the buyers paid cash.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Aug. 18.-- Mrs. John T. Dorrance entertained at dinner at Kenarden Lodge tonight.

Earl Baldwin of Bewdley, former Prime Minister of Great Britain, who is now in this country, was requested yesterday by the American Christian Emergency Council for Palestine to inform his government of the alleged repudiation of the Palestine mandate.

ALBANY, Aug. 18.--Payment of $7,250,095 unemployment insurance benefits in July was reported today by Miss Frieda S. Miller, Industrial Commissioner.

DANZIG, Aug. 18 (AP).--Nazi District Leader Albert Forster, reviewing the first parade of the newly militarized home defense force, declared tonight that "Poland has become the only possible attacker" of Danzig. For this reason, he declared, Danzig's new armaments had become necessary.

BERLIN, Aug. 18.--The international crisis over Danzig produced no fresh development on the German side today although official and press comment left no doubt that the deadlock, as viewed here, is drifting to a climax that may be as sudden as it is destined to be tragic.

PARIS, Aug. 18.--Watteau's masterpiece, "L'Indifferent," was seriously damaged by the "restoration" it underwent while absent from the Louvre, according to a report made today to the investigating magistrate by Jean Gabriel Goulinat, painter and art expert.

Erie County, N.Y., which includes the city of Buffalo, has sold an issue of $1,000,000 of certificates of indebtedness to the Marine Trust Company of Buffalo and associates, according to word received here yesterday. FIRST ARMY HEADQUARTERS, Plattsburg, N.Y., Aug. 18. --Shelter tents dotted the lush fields and rocky hillsides of the Champlain Valley tonight as tired troops of the First Army bivouacked close behind the "front lines" in their first overnight problem.

WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 18.-- Judge Ernest A. Inglis today deferred to Monday the sentencing of Mayor Frank Hayes and eighteen others found guilty Wednesday of conspiring to defraud the city of Waterbury.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18.--The Weather Bureau's hurricane warning service is able to give ample warning of the time of arrival of hurricanes and their intensity, Commander F.W. Reichelderfer, chief of the Bureau, said today.

PARIS, Sept. 8.--Those in France who are responsible for the conduct of this war to its successful conclusion are taking no chances. Every civilian's mind is being distracted from the main issue by the immediate issue of the numerous restrictions to which he must conform and new decrees that he must fulfill.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8.--The Coast Guard today withdrew the cutter Northland from participation in the projected Antarctic expedition of Admiral Richard F. Byrd. The Admiral announced later in the day, however, that he would carry on without the Northland.

ALBANY, Sept. 10.--The July birth rate of 14.5 per 1,000 population in this State was the lowest ever recorded for that month with a single exception, the State Department of Health stated today. The death rate of 9.4 has never been lower in July.
